roar! this memorial day weekend was the grand opening of the new luna park down at coney island. it should be a fun trip!
here i am out side the gates to the new luna park. i can't wait to go inside! roar!

roar! this memorial day weekend was the grand opening of the new luna park down at coney island. the original luna park was one of the first amusement parks and it opened in 1903. it had some really amazing rides and was the playground for both celebrities and chimps alike.
here i am out side the gates to the new luna park. i can't wait to go inside! roar!

this memorial day weekend was the grand opening of the new luna park down at coney island. eventually new amusement park were built in the area. astroland was the most recent amusement park to sit on the property but that went out of business 3 years ago.

then of course there is the coney island cyclone! this is a classic roller coaster that has been around since the original luna park days. it was built in 1925 and designed by vernon keenan.

this is a classic roller coaster that has been around since the original luna park days. to me the cyclone represents the pinnacle of classic wooden coaster design. hanging out at the park was fun but i decided to head over and check out the beach and walk on the board walk.
here i am over on the boardwalk. you can see how busy it is here above the boardwalk but i wonder what is going on underneath it? roar!

here i am over on the boardwalk. you can see how busy it is here above the boardwalk but i wonder what is going on underneath it? in the background you can see the original parachute drop from the 1939 worlds fair in flushing meadows park in queens.

you can see how busy it is here above the boardwalk but i wonder what is going on underneath it? in the background you can see the original parachute drop from the 1939 worlds fair in flushing meadows park in queens. it was moved to coney island when they renovated the park for the 1964 worlds fair.

i was getting hungry so i headed over to the famous nathan's for some famous hot dogs. nathan's has been around for almost a hundred years and has some of the best hot dogs in the city. roar!

i was getting hungry so i headed over to the famous nathan's for some famous hot dogs. nathan's has been around for almost a hundred years and has some of the best hot dogs in the city. the stand opened in 1916 and is the second hot dog stand in the united states.

nathan's has been around for almost a hundred years and has some of the best hot dogs in the city. today was a pretty fun trip to coney island! but next time i come back i'll make sure its a weekday so it isn't so crowded.

my family and i just got back from spending our holiday vacation in new york city. early on tuesday 12 4 morning i took the subway down to rockefeller center to photograph the christmas tree before the sun came up. i left our hotel room about 4 45 am and took the subway downtown.

instagram photo corrie m avila my first thought was who in the world took that photograph and why was that person not helping the man pull himself out? i won't get too social worker y on you but that man in the subway was in shock. frozen in trauma and in fear looking at the oncoming train.

early on tuesday 12 4 morning i took the subway down to rockefeller center to photograph the christmas tree before the sun came up. it wasn't until later that i knew why. tomorrow marks one week since a nyc man was pushed to his death in front of a moving subway. but what really caught my attention was the fact that the new york post published a photo that was snapped seconds before the man was crushed to death by the oncoming subway train.

instagram photo corrie m avila my first thought was who in the world took that photograph and why was that person not helping the man pull himself out? according to the article and video in the above link by the ny post he also said he feared for himself because at one point the supposed perp was coming straight at him. he claims he didn't even know he had this shot until the police were looking at his photos trying to glean usable information in the to catch the perpetrator.

i spent a lovely afternoon in the company of little miss g's godmother today and she has kindly requested that i wrote about nyc as she is going for new year's eve with her amazing husband whom g adores and her lovely family. writing about nyc is the subject of an entire blog let alone a post but in the interest of time my sore back and my need for sleep i have decided to channel it down to my top 10

pre baby mr h and i used to go to nyc every year religiously for the second bank holiday in may which in the states often coincides with memorial day and in our household coincides with mr h's birthday celebrations. we have not been in the last 2 years owing to a certain little missy coming to disrupt alter our travel plans but rest assured big apple we'll come back soon. 2. whilst the empire state building is amazing it has one major flaw when you are in it you cannot see it but let me introduce you to my other tall friend the rockefeller center and its top of the rock observation deck from which you can see the beauty that it is central park from pretty close surely much better than from the empire state and from which you can see south way to the empire state and the rest of manhattan!

i spent a lovely afternoon in the company of little miss g's godmother today and she has kindly requested that i wrote about nyc as she is going for new year's eve with her amazing husband whom g adores and her lovely family. writing about nyc is the subject of an entire blog let alone a post but in the interest of time my sore back and my need for sleep i have decided to channel it down to my top 10

pre baby mr h and i used to go to nyc every year religiously for the second bank holiday in may which in the states often coincides with memorial day and in our household coincides with mr h's birthday celebrations. we have not been in the last 2 years owing to a certain little missy coming to disrupt alter our travel plans but rest assured big apple we'll come back soon. so in no particular order here are my top 10 favourite things about new york city 1. new york city wouldn't be new york city without the empire state building so any visit to the big apple requires a trip up the famous lift elevator.

i spent a lovely afternoon in the company of little miss g's godmother today and she has kindly requested that i wrote about nyc as she is going for new year's eve with her amazing husband whom g adores and her lovely family. writing about nyc is the subject of an entire blog let alone a post but in the interest of time my sore back and my need for sleep i have decided to channel it down to my top 10

pre baby mr h and i used to go to nyc every year religiously for the second bank holiday in may which in the states often coincides with memorial day and in our household coincides with mr h's birthday celebrations. we have not been in the last 2 years owing to a certain little missy coming to disrupt alter our travel plans but rest assured big apple we'll come back soon. 2. whilst the empire state building is amazing it has one major flaw when you are in it you cannot see it but let me introduce you to my other tall friend the rockefeller center and its top of the rock observation deck from which you can see the beauty that it is central park from pretty close surely much better than from the empire state and from which you can see south way to the empire state and the rest of manhattan!

3. a visit to ellis island is a real must to understand the history of the city and the history of the country. it is an amazing museum and the ferry that takes you there has a certain statue of liberty to circumnavigate too which is a real added bonus. i think it sums up the spirit of the italians so call me a wop and i personally won't get offended but don't call an italian american that they are very politically correct and sensitive about most things.

3. a visit to ellis island is a real must to understand the history of the city and the history of the country. it is an amazing museum and the ferry that takes you there has a certain statue of liberty to circumnavigate too which is a real added bonus. i warn you it is a bit of a hassle to get to ellis island as they limit tickets worth booking in advance and you need to have a very thorough airport like metal detector check in but once on the island it all becomes worth it!

it is an amazing museum and the ferry that takes you there has a certain statue of liberty to circumnavigate too which is a real added bonus. i warn you it is a bit of a hassle to get to ellis island as they limit tickets worth booking in advance and you need to have a very thorough airport like metal detector check in but once on the island it all becomes worth it! i think it sums up the spirit of the italians so call me a wop and i personally won't get offended but don't call an italian american that they are very politically correct and sensitive about most things.
4. the moma has to be one of my favourite museums of all time! i know i said that about some parisian museums last month but hey sue me i love museums! oh i so could live at the moma!

4. the moma has to be one of my favourite museums of all time! i know i said that about some parisian museums last month but hey sue me i love museums! by the way don't use hey sue me about nothing with americans as some you will find out might just decide to .

by the way don't use hey sue me about nothing with americans as some you will find out might just decide to . the moma has one of the best locations in the city it is airy easy to browse has outdoor space amazing books incredible design pieces in its shop. and best of all has the most genius collection of modern art. it stretches from paintings to drawings from sculptures to photographs it display classic object of design like my prized olivetti valentina typewriter in the same building as prints and illustrated books.

5. the guggenheim museum is just up the road well a fair few blocks but this is new york taxis are plentiful! from the moma and one could just spend hours in the building even if it didn't have any art in it. frank lloyd wright designed this building in such a fascinating way that i often wonder if i like the building better than the art or the other way around.

5. the guggenheim museum is just up the road well a fair few blocks but this is new york taxis are plentiful! from the moma and one could just spend hours in the building even if it didn't have any art in it. the idea is that instead of visiting rooms one after the other you just get scooped up all the way to the top by elevator this is about nyc so i speak american get it?

5. the guggenheim museum is just up the road well a fair few blocks but this is new york taxis are plentiful! the idea is that instead of visiting rooms one after the other you just get scooped up all the way to the top by elevator this is about nyc so i speak american get it? and then you walk your way down through a circular ramp whilst browsing the art on show.

6. as we are in central park area one cannot avoid talking about this fascinating green lung in the heart of manhattan. it is huge it has ponds lakes playgrounds and even horse ridden carriages if you want to re live that carrie and mr big moment. american sports go in seasons so there is nearly always something on offer.

6. as we are in central park area one cannot avoid talking about this fascinating green lung in the heart of manhattan. it is huge it has ponds lakes playgrounds and even horse ridden carriages if you want to re live that carrie and mr big moment. central park is fun in the cold and hot weather as it is always lively.

6. as we are in central park area one cannot avoid talking about this fascinating green lung in the heart of manhattan. it is huge it has ponds lakes playgrounds and even horse ridden carriages if you want to re live that carrie and mr big moment. that's your free taste to american sports but if you are more committed to see some real champions then book a ticket to see the yankees or the mets if baseball is your thing the knicks if you are more of an indoor basketball dude or the giants if you want to see what the american call football.

7. meatpacking district bleecker street and the village. every good trip to nyc needs to have dedicated shopping time. i still love the area and i often end up walking in washington square park trying to imagine what it used to be like in the 1950s and 1960s yet very much enjoying the informal and fun vibe that it still retains today.
7. meatpacking district bleecker street and the village. every good trip to nyc needs to have dedicated shopping time. pastis in the meatpacking district will be a good starting and ending point.

it is a trendy french bistro that does the most amazing brunches to fuel up for a shopping day in town or delicious dinners for recharging the batteries before a night out. first the artists of the beat generation in the 1950s then bob dylan the velvet underground and jimi hendrix to name a few in the 1960s used to hang out in this area of new york which was very much the centre of counterculture and bohemian lifestyle. i still love the area and i often end up walking in washington square park trying to imagine what it used to be like in the 1950s and 1960s yet very much enjoying the informal and fun vibe that it still retains today.
8. soho is made for shopping. every amazing brand is there. and off i go again!
8. soho is made for shopping. every amazing brand is there. if 5th avenue is a lot about window shopping soho is where the amazing brands rub hands with the more affordable but still cool.

if 5th avenue is a lot about window shopping soho is where the amazing brands rub hands with the more affordable but still cool. highlights for me are the prada flagship store which is just out of this world cool and amazing marni bloomingdale's much better than the big sister branch uptown the apple store even though in this case it cannot merely compete with the apple store extravaganza on 5th avenue the huge uniqlo store the very new york catherine malandrino and marc jacobs stores. if i am hungry at some point throughout my shopping trip dean and deluca is there to feed me and recharge me with amazing food and atmosphere.

9. eating out in new york is heaven. every cuisine is catered for and taxis are everywhere to get from one place to the next. i can never bring myself to go underground to get from a to b when the skyline is so interesting and the taxis are everywhere.

9. eating out in new york is heaven. every cuisine is catered for and taxis are everywhere to get from one place to the next. i always enjoy a good meal at the celebrity filled crowd at the spotted pig i am bias toward pastis as i have already confessed and i find it strange yet satisfying to eat at a train station when it is the grand central oyster bar and restaurant.

i always enjoy a good meal at the celebrity filled crowd at the spotted pig i am bias toward pastis as i have already confessed and i find it strange yet satisfying to eat at a train station when it is the grand central oyster bar and restaurant. mr h and i are fond of certain places and will often return there on that note a drink at the maritime hotel is always nice but we also do our research and try to find authentic local restaurants with good food and good prices. 10. once in new york forget the tube subway just wear comfortable shoes and walk.

here is my top 10 but you are right how could i miss it out? the reason it has not made it to my top 10 is that i have not been there yet. i can't wait to see it and walk it with mr h and little miss g.

here is my top 10 but you are right how could i miss it out? the reason it has not made it to my top 10 is that i have not been there yet. however it is also the very reason why i know i am returning to new york sooner rather than later pushchair baby and all the high line!

however it is also the very reason why i know i am returning to new york sooner rather than later pushchair baby and all the high line! built in the 1930s to lift dangerous freight trains off the street and left unused since 1980 this stretch of railroad is now an amazing park that goes through buildings and give the nyc skyline a whole new viewpoint and look. i can't wait to see it and walk it with mr h and little miss g.

neighborhood food tours are all the rage in cities across the country. but nowhere do they seem to be more successful than within the boundaries of that gastronome's mecca known as new york city. mangia!
in the heart of the old italian section of greenwich village.

neighborhood food tours are all the rage in cities across the country. but nowhere do they seem to be more successful than within the boundaries of that gastronome's mecca known as new york city. and one of the reasons why this is so is the original foods of new york tours fnyt .
in the heart of the old italian section of greenwich village.

yesterday fnyt celebrated its 15th birthday and we joined the festivities by taking an original greenwich village food tour savoring the old italian section and the quaint surroundings of one of the most historic areas on manhattan. we decided to take this tour for three reasons 1 we hadn't been in the storied greenwich village area of the big apple for years and we longed to discover it anew beyond the touristy environs of washington square. and so there we were eating our way through picturesque area of the village with our superbly informative and delightfully entertaining tour guide raheem as we wandered in and out of small and medium sized locally owned business and restaurants all of which offer up the freshest culinary treats.
in the heart of the old italian section of greenwich village.

great food and cary grant's nyc hideaway! neighborhood food tours are all the rage in cities across the country. mangia!

great food and cary grant's nyc hideaway! neighborhood food tours are all the rage in cities across the country. but nowhere do they seem to be more successful than within the boundaries of that gastronome's mecca known as new york city.

yesterday fnyt celebrated its 15th birthday and we joined the festivities by taking an original greenwich village food tour savoring the old italian section and the quaint surroundings of one of the most historic areas on manhattan. we decided to take this tour for three reasons 1 we hadn't been in the storied greenwich village area of the big apple for years and we longed to discover it anew beyond the touristy environs of washington square. and so there we were eating our way through picturesque area of the village with our superbly informative and delightfully entertaining tour guide raheem as we wandered in and out of small and medium sized locally owned business and restaurants all of which offer up the freshest culinary treats.

terrace bridge central park april 7 2010rob hickman keith nelsonwe arranged to meet at columbus circle at 11. with minutes to spare as is custom keith ran to the deli and grabbed and egg sandwich and coffee. the park was swarming with people due in part to the unusually warm early april weather nyc was experiencing. a return expedition is being planned.

terrace bridge central park april 7 2010rob hickman keith nelsonwe arranged to meet at columbus circle at 11. with minutes to spare as is custom keith ran to the deli and grabbed and egg sandwich and coffee. the park was swarming with people due in part to the unusually warm early april weather nyc was experiencing. the park was filled with baby carriages dog walkers foreign tourists senior citizens cyclists runners roller bladers sunbathers leisurely class folks and youngsters unable to cope with the first day back to school after spring break.

the park was filled with baby carriages dog walkers foreign tourists senior citizens cyclists runners roller bladers sunbathers leisurely class folks and youngsters unable to cope with the first day back to school after spring break. we discovered an additional 13 bridges and traverses that had received little attention or were completely overlooked in our preparation source materials. the first warm weather ride of the season brought to light the need for better hydration systems for the upcoming 5 borough bike tour. a few bridges later kyle opted to return home to feed and care for his canine companion leaving only keith and rob to finish the spans of central park. and so they rolled. the last two standing rolled into the subway inn one of the east side's only remaining dive bars.

started apr 7 2010 11 18 09 amride time 5 58 15distance 15. 37 milesaverage 2. 82 miles hrfastest speed 26. 70 miles hrclimb 551 feetmore on the terrace bridge calvert vaux was according to legend inspired by the orangerie at the palace of versailles in paris because the designs of both spaces are similar. hidden under the arches are colorful tiles on the ceiling made by the minton company of stoke on trent england. made mostly of sandstone and granite.
